captions.text: Welcome to Peru!
Hi travellers! Welcome to Peru.
This episode is going to be finger-licking good
because we are going to try every food available!
I'm here with 2 Peruvian bloggers:
Jose, who's been away for a while,
and Frank, a well-known blogger from Peru.
We've been invited here by Encounter Latin America to live some special local experiences
We're going to eat, we're going to explore, and we're going to discover some culture.
What are we waiting for? Let's go!
Let's eat!
We've stopped in San Martin Square here in central Lima to check out a small but interesting detail:
if you look at the head of the 'Madre Patria' statue,
which is beneath the monument,
you'll see that on her head is a llama,
but it is a llama - the animal
and what the sculptor really wanted
was a "flame" llama ("llama" also means  "flame" in Spanish)
he went on a trip and when he came back his assistant had already place the animal, and there she stay.
We're now in the San Francisco Convent,
very close to San Martin Square,
but what a surprise we had in the catacombs below the convent!
It's a place with thousands upon thousands of skeletons
from many centuries. Really surprising!
We're in Cordano Bar, which specializes in ham sandwiches
from the north of Peru, and Pisco Sours.
Were actually 2 blocks away from where Pisco Sour was invented.
This bar has been opened since 1905
and having a Pisco here is something you can't miss. Cheers!
Even though it looks like it, this isn't Hong Kong.
Peru is characterized by its cultural diversity,
and the Chinese presence can be felt everywhere,
especially here, in Chinatown.
"Chifa" is the fusion of Chinese and Peruvian food,
and here in San Joy Lao  a very traditional restaurant,
we sampled just a few of the hundreds of dishes they have available.
Right now we're in Ayahuasca, a bar in Barranco, one of my favourite areas of Lima,
where we're going to check out all the fusions, and different drinks prepared with pisco.
What a great place: loads of colour and energy, a brilliant atmosphere. I loved this place!
It was different from this morning when we tried traditional pisco,
so we decided to try every single cocktail to see the difference...
we tried ...
..and I can't remember anymore.
Let's talk about the entrees, Jose! They were so delicious.
All I can say is: way too much pisco! What a hangover it was ...
Well guys, as hard as it was to get up this morning, we're on a gastronomic tour....
and we have to start eating well from the get go
, that's why we came here, to a very traditional spot in Miraflores -
it's called La Preferida, and it's on a corner where,
for more than 50 years, people have been eating delicious food.
Peru is a country filled with culture -
it has ancient, ancestral culture, which Peru has a great deal of respect for, as much as contemporary culture.
This is a huaca, of which there are many in Lima. It's a pre-Incan ceremonial temple.
I've always said there's no better way of getting to know a city than cycling around it.
We cycled from Miraflores to Barranco
all along the seafront. It's lovely, with all the people doing exercise;
it was a really cool experience.
Barranco is a very traditional area of Lima
it's very bohemian and the mornings here are very relaxed,
walking across the "Puente de los suspiros"
And at night it's a very lively, party neighbourhood,
but also somewhere where you can drink a coffee in an art gallery,
go to the cinema, listen to live music:
it's a district that I really love.
*Naming alI the many different kinds of fish for sale*
And next door to Barranco is Chorrillos, which is a typical fisherman's neighbourhood;
up the cliffs there's a secret that is not quite a secret anymore
Sonia Restaurant, owned by Mr. Freddy,
which has been visited by Ferran Adria, Anthony Bourdain, Gaston Acurio and all the bests chefs.
We had the honour of eating with him in his own restaurant.
This is the best fish I've eaten in my whole life!
And now back to Miraflores in search of adventure
OK, we're going to paraglide over some spectacular places!
It's a spectacular view flying over Miraflores:
all along the seafront, with the sea to the right, full of surfers,
other paragliders and the city to the left.
A highly recommended experience for everyone.
I loved  " Choritos a la Chalaca" and I told Jose and Frank to take me where they come from.
It's a really tranquil spot, with some really relaxed beaches
and the best part is that you can see a lovely panorama of ships, sailing boats;
it's really relaxed and the water is so transparent.
Off all the Peruvian food, I like these more than anything else!
Frank, thanks so much for the invite. Lima; what a beautiful city you have! We did so much in such little time.
For me it was so exciting coming back to the city I was born in,
discovering it as a blogger, and meeting up with Frank. And the food!
Spectacular! And we haven't even see 100%, we've seen just 10%.
I hope there'll be a next time, so we can do everything we didn't have time for!
Of course, it has been a spectacular destination.
Well, it's over, we have to go home! Bye!

title: Lima: Tour Gastronómico en Perú - 3 Travel Bloggers (English Subtitles)
